title: Australia’s dirty secret exposed
text:

Environment Minister Greg Hunt uses Wikipedia research to dispute the relationship between climate change and bushfires. Courtesy: BBC Radio October 24th 2013 2 years ago /video/video.news.com.au/News/ 
IT’S crunch time, Australia. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has said the country could be in for major “adjustments” on climate change policy by 2017, ahead of a major UN convention in Paris on the issue. 
It comes as French Ambassador Christophe Lecourtier said the “planets are becoming more aligned” ahead of the Paris summit where 200 nations will meet to set a new version of the Kyoto Protocol that could have a huge impact on every area of Australian life. 
So far, 146 countries representing 87 per cent of global emissions have submitted a plan for the event, which is expected to deliver an agreement on how to create a “low emission, climate resilient and sustainable future” that will prevent global temperatures rising more than two degrees — the line in the sand against the worst impacts of climate change. The Adani mine in Queensland could provide the same amount of greenhouse gas emissions a year as Norway and Sweden combined. Australians are sun-lovers, but how hot do we want it to get? Picture: REUTERS/David Gray PM Malcolm Turnbull has signalled Australia could be due for a change in policy after 2017 but has not said whether he will attend the Paris negotiations. Environmental groups fear the Adani mine will be a disaster for the Great Barrier Reef. The massive project is still waiting on financial investment. Picture: AFP/SARAH LAI The Aletsch Glacier is one of Europe’s biggest glaciers yet could vanish in the lifetime of people born today because of climate change. Picture: REUTERS/Denis Balibouse. Aussie farmers are also vulnerable to the effects of a changing climate. Picture: Nathan Dyer Australia is a unique position to contribute to the debate on climate change, experts say. United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change executive secretary Christiana Figueres said the number of commitments made by individual nations has “grown from a steady stream into a sweeping flood” which create an “unparalleled opportunity” to create a new future. 
But with Australia holding the ignominious position of producing the “ highest emissions levels per capita among all major countries ,” what does that mean for our carbon-loving lifestyle?
